bibl.title: Letter from [Laura Armistead Carter] to A.M. Stimson, May 6, 1923

div1.p: [Laura Carter] writes that Henry Carter believes that parasites do not develop in mosquitoes below 61 degrees . He believes last year's cases of malaria were caused by females that had been hibernating.

div1.head: Letter from [Laura Armistead Carter] to A.M. Stimson, May 6, 1923
div1.opener:
N. M. C.
Stimson
2121 California St., N. W.,
Washington, D. C.,
May 6, 1923.
Dear Doctor Stimson:
div1.p:
I am enclosing a reprint of Father's, which I had in mind last
night when you were telling me of Colonel James' statements.

Father says that there have been one or two articles by Angus
MacDonald since the war accompanied with temperature records of the
districts in England: That MacDonald takes the same view that he
did--that with a temperature below 61° the parasites do not develope
in the mosquitoes and that the infection will naturally die out in
any reasonably cold summer--certainly if a succession of them occurs.

That--Colonel James to the contrary--control of mosquito product-
ion was used and depended on during and soon after the war in the
worst infected districts south of the Thames. For so much of the work
as James was in charge of, quinine sterilization of reported cases
and, to some extent, of carriers were the measures relied on. In
Father's judjment while this hastened the elimination of malaria
it was really unnecessary and the work yielded he supposes from 10 to
15 shillings value per £/of expenditure. This was also the opinion
of Ross and Osler. James is no field man. All his reputation--which
is well deserved--is as a bench man.

He, Father, asks you to note the absolute absence of malignant
tertian--although nearly 30% of the introduced infections were of
that character. The developement of this parasite requires a some-
what higher temperature than the benign tertian.

He says that MacDonald also agrees with him in his claim that a

considerable number of the early cases of malarial fever are infect-
ions caused by the hibernated females and not, as they had hitherto
been considered, by relapses from last year's infections and that
he was glad to have the support of so good a man.

With very best remembrances from us both to Mrs. Stimson and
yourself.
